properties.Title: Update To Civil Emergency Alert Issued By Government Of Saskatchewan
properties.Summary:
Description: Update for the Civil Emergency Alert issued by the Government of Saskatchewan. The state of emergency in Saskatchewan remains in effect. UPDATE: Phase 1 of Re-Open Saskatchewan became effective May 4, 2020. All Public Health Orders continue to apply during the implementation of Phase 1 Re-Open Saskatchewan. Continue to monitor and follow all public health orders on the Saskatchewan.ca COVID 19 website. Continue to practice physical distancing. Avoid gatherings with people outside your immediate household. Avoid unnecessary travel. Self-isolate if returning from foreign travel or if experiencing any symptoms. Wash your hands often. Together, we are reducing the risk. We can pull together by staying apart.
Expires: 2020-05-18T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2020-05-11T15:47:21-06:00, 16E965F0-5686-DC9D-B462-39AFEB18B77D
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Another late season snowfall. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Locations: Extreme northwestern New Brunswick. Time span: this morning into tonight. Remarks: Snow is expected to continue through the day before tapering off tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-12T23:38:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-12T07:39:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3186171529.2020
Area: Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall amounts will reach or slightly exceed 10 centimetres over higher elevations of Montmagny and the Lower St Lawrence. Quickly accumulating snow may result in difficult road conditions and be an obstacle to travel. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-13T02:59:31-00:00

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Temperatures will drop to near or slightly below the freezing mark overnight tonight. The unseasonably cool weather will also last until Thursday. As a result, the frost advisory over Southwestern Quebec could be maintained until Thursday morning in some areas. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-13T07:28:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-12T15:29:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0683132510.2020
Area: Saint-Jérôme area, Lachute area, Saint-Eustache area, Longueuil - Varennes area, Laval area, Montréal Island area, Châteauguay - La Prairie area, Soulanges area, Vaudreuil area, Saint-Rémi area, Valleyfield - Beauharnois area, Hemmingford area, Huntingdon area, Berthierville - Saint-Gabriel area, Rawdon - Joliette area, Mascouche area, Sorel - Yamaska area, Saint-Hyacinthe - Acton Vale area, Verchères - Beloeil area, Saint-Jean - Marieville area, Lacolle area, Bécancour - Villeroy area, Victoriaville area, Nicolet area, Drummondville area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. An approaching low pressure system from the east has spread snow and strong north winds into Naujaat today. Blizzard conditions with visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected to persist into the early evening hours. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-13T05:22:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-12T18:24:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1431348919.2020
Area: Naujaat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected in the Natuashish area. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Time span: beginning Wednesday morning and diminishing in intensity Thursday morning. Snow may continue into Friday, but accumulations will not be significant. Remarks: The Nain area will receive 5 to 10 cm of snow before conditions improve on Thursday morning. Strong northerly winds will develop Wednesday night and may cause a brief period of reduced visibility in blow snow, especially over exposed areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-05-13T05:46:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-12T13:47:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1757276054.2020
Area: Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant prolonged snow event is expected. Total snowfall: 30 to 60 cm. Locations: Hopedale to Makkovik. Time span: beginning overnight tonight. Snow will gradually ease in intensity on Thursday; however, snow and slight accumulations may continue into Friday or Saturday. Remarks: Highest snowfall accumulations are expected inland and over higher terrain and may locally exceed the amounts mentioned above. Areas along the coast may experience some periods of rain or wet snow, which could drastically reduce snowfall accumulation. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-05-13T05:47:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-12T13:48:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3240832309.2020
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures will drop well below the freezing mark again tonight resulting in frost or freeze conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm (heaviest over eastern areas). Locations: Churchill Falls and Churchill Valley. Time span: Wednesday and Wednesday night. Remarks: Snow will begin Wednesday morning or afternoon and persist into Wednesday night or Thursday. Motorists travelling towards Happy Valley-Goose Bay should be aware that a snowfall warning has been issued for the Upper Lake Melville area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-05-13T05:47:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-12T13:48:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0791136158.2020
Area: Churchill Valley, Churchill Falls and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Locations: inland areas from Lodge Bay to Cartwright, including the Eagle River portion of the Trans Labrador Highway, the Upper Lake Melville area and Rigolet. Time span: this evening until Wednesday afternoon for most areas. Continuing on Wednesday night for the Upper Lake Melville area and Rigolet. Remarks: Areas along the coast from Black Tickle to Lodge Bay may receive 10 to 15 mm of rain after seeing near 5 cm of snow this evening. For the Upper Lake Melville and Rigolet areas, snow or a mixture of snow and rain, will continue Wednesday night into Thursday. At this time it is it uncertain whether additional snow will accumulate or if it will remain wet without any significant further amounts. These details will updated in future forecasts once the outcome becomes more certain. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-05-13T05:55:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-12T13:56:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0392455031.2020
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected between Red Bay and Lodge Bay. Total snowfall: near 15 cm. Time span: this evening until overnight tonight. Remarks: Highest snowfall amounts expected along the Trans Labrador Highway between Red Bay and Lodge Bay. Communities from L'Anse-au-Clair to Red Bay can expect near 5 cm of snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
